Award.AwardTitle: Capacity Building: Collaborative Research: Integrated Learning Environment for Cyber Security of Smart Grid

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ensuring the cyber-security of the smart grid raises significant interest amongst both general public and researchers. However, the corresponding education programs fall behind in many aspects. Very limited curriculum or hands-on learning resources are available for security education about the smart grid, especially for the mutual impacts between cyber and physical systems. To bridge this gap, this project is developing an integrated simulation environment dedicated to smart grid education programs, and is designing a suite of course modules and hands-on projects focusing on security of modern power systems. Through federating the control network simulator with the Power Grid Simulator Program, this project covers both cyber and physical systems underpinning smart grid operations. The research team is carrying out well-planned evaluation and dissemination activities to assess the effectiveness of the innovative instructional materials and promote their wide adoption. Rigorous evaluation procedures are being used by experienced independent evaluators. The research team is implementing the new instructional materials in six courses at three participating institutions, and the project is promoting the wide adoption of the approaches through two faculty development workshops.

Intellectual Merits: This project is designing a first-of-its-kind smart grid simulation environment dedicated to security education programs that covers both cyber and physical systems. This environment and the educational materials provide transformative learning experiences for students on future electric energy systems and promote research and education in this interdisciplinary field. Through the dissemination efforts such as faculty development workshops and outreach activities, the project establishes a student education and training pipeline that attracts high school students to CS and EE majors, equips college students with much needed cyber and physical knowledge and skills for secure power systems, and prepares them for the challenges of working in the future power industry.

Broader Impacts: This project provides a new method to train qualified workforce to fill tens of thousands of open positions in the fast evolving smart grid industry and improve the sustainability and security of future power systems. The project provides interdisciplinary research experiences in cyber-physical systems involving power grid, networks, and security to both graduate and undergraduate students. Minority and under-represented students also benefit from the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed an integrated simulation framework of smart grids for security educational purposes, design and implement a suite of course modules and hands-on exercises upon the system, and contributed to the establishment of an education and training pipeline for information security workforce in future power industry through carefully planned evaluation and dissemination activities.

Intellectual Merit:

(1) While the research on security of smart grid has attracted a lot of efforts, the corresponding educational programs fall behind in many ways. This project tries to address this deficiency. The proposed educational materials and hands-on projects will provide students new interdisciplinary learning experiences in computer security and power systems. Students in both CS and EE majors will be better prepared for future jobs in this very active industry. (2) In the past few years, cyber-physical systems (CPS) have become a driving force for the development of computer science and information security since the real-life applications put new challenges to many existing approaches. One major hurdle that restricts further advances of CPS is the learning curve to enter a specific engineering field such as power systems. The development, adoption procedures, and achievements of the project will help subsequent projects to better understand the learning curves so that corresponding schemes can be designed. Graduates who are equipped with the knowledge in both CS and EE majors have the potential to solve problems in power industry through innovative approaches and bring new advances. (3) Internet of Things (IoT) is a natural extension of sensor networks. With the fast increasing number of deployed sensors, the impacts of data manipulation attacks on system security and stability start to attract more attention. Our efforts in the last year try to link the two parts together so that students can better understand the relationship between data and systems. In this way, they will be better prepared for data centered job opportunities. (4) The project integrates the latest advances in computer security, networks, industry control systems, and power systems. In this way, the project achievements will promote interdisciplinary research and education, and provide such experiences to both graduate and undergraduate students who participate in the project. (5) Cyber physical systems are an active field that includes many different types of real-life applications. The success of this project will explore new ways for education and career preparation in this type of interdisciplinary fields. The integration of computer sciences with other majors such as intelligent transportation, smart healthcare, smart city, and intelligent manufacturing will benefit from the achievements. Built upon the experiences from this project, we have secured a new project from NSF SaTC Education on Security of Advanced Manufacturing Systems. (6) Through directly working with industry companies, we collect a comprehensive view of the industry need as well as the security aspects that demand improvements. 

Broader Impacts:

(1) This project provides research and development experiences to multiple graduate students at participating institutions.  (2) One major objective of the SFS program is career preparation of future workforce. The proposed materials have been integrated into both graduate level and undergraduate level security and infrastructure protection courses at participating institutions. The course modules on Smart Grid security have been integrated into the course “Principles of Information Security and Privacy” and “Wireless Network Security” at UNCC, which are essential courses in our Cyber Security Master’s Program. These courses have been offered by the PI almost every year and they usually attract more than 80 students each time. (3) The PI at Texas A&M integrated the modules into the course Power System State Estimation, and have more than 80 students cumulatively taking this course. (4) The team has done a number of outreach activities including broader community seminars at Internet2, and power systems engineering research center.
